titleStmt.title: Na and Ca tracer diffusion in plagioclase glasses and supercooled melts

analytic.title: Na and Ca tracer diffusion in plagioclase glasses and supercooled melts

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: The diffusion of Na and Ca was investigated in various glasses of plagioclase compositions by the residual activity method in the temperature range 400-1000 °C at normal pressure. An anomalous diffusion was observed for both Na and Ca diffusion in high-calcic glasses. This behaviour is afiributed to a partially interrupted contact between the sample and the activated surface layer. Na diffusivity decreases strongly with increasing CaA12Si208 (An) content of the glass, especially for An-rich glasses. By contrast, the compositional dependence of Ca diffusion is less pronounced. For example, at 800 ° C the diffusivity of Ca in a glass containing 60 mole% An is lower only by a factor of 5 compared to pure NaA1Si308 (Ab) glass whereas it is by a factor of 60 for Na. Arrhenius plots of Na diffusivities in the Anso and AnTo glasses showed marked changes of slope, probably caused by the transformation from a glass to a supercooled melt. Apparent transformation temperatures obtained from these plots are lower than those obtained calorimetrically. This indicates, that relaxation processes occur in these glasses at temperatures below the onset of non-linear changes in macroscopic properties.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Tracer diffusion is a well-established method to study atomic movement in solids, glasses and melts. The use of stable or radioactive isotopes allows one to investigate specifically the thermal mobility of an element without introducing chemical potential gradients. The temperature and compositional dependencies of the tracer diffusivity give insight into the dynamic and structural properties of the material. For glasses and melts these diffusion data may be used to model properties of geological interest, such as material transport, viscosity or crystallization kinetics.

In glass science, tracer-diffusion techniques have been used for more then forty years. A summary of early studies is given by Frischat (1975). In the last twenty years tracer-diffusion experiments have been performed more intensively by Earth scientists to study kinetic properties of glasses and melts. Diffusivities of alkali and alkaline-earth cations in simple silicate systems of albite and orthoclase composition were determined by Jambon and Carron (1976), Jambon and Delbove (1977) and Jambon and Semet (1978). Their data demonstrate the influence of ionic radius and charge on cation mobility. In addition to these investigations on glasses with simple compositions, an increasing effort has been made to get data for more complex natural melt and glass systems (Sippel, 1963;Carron, 1968;Winchell and Norman, 1969;Hofmann and Magaritz, 1977;Jambon and Carron, 1978;Jambon and Semet, 1978;Magaritz and Hofmann, 1978a, b;Lowry et al., 1981Lowry et al., , 1982;;Jambon 1982;Cunningham et al., 1983;Henderson et al., 1986) The present study is concerned with tracer-diffusion processes in glasses of plagioclase compositions. The quasi-binary system Na-A1SiaOs-CaA12Si208 (or Ab-An) is interesting in that it changes from high silica content ( Ab ) to low silica content (An). Along the Ab-An join, Na + + Si 4+ are replaced continuously by Ca R+-t-AI 3+. Although the structure remains fully polymerized, i.e. this substitution produces no non-bridging oxygens (NBO's), there are considerable structural changes in the glasses caused by variation of the Na/Ca ratio.

In order to study variations in structural and dynamic properties in this system, the radioactive isotope 22Na was used as an atomic sensor in tracer-diffusion experiments. Some additional experiments were performed using 45Ca. For two compositions, the investigated temperature range was extended from the field of glass to that of supercooled melt by means to temperatures above the glass transformation temperature Tg.

div.head: Materials and experimental procedure
div.p: Glasses of nominal compositions An60 and An90 were obtained by melting gels at 1600 ° C and quenching the melts in air. The two other glasses (nominal compositions Anso and An70) were prepared in the Schott ® laboratory (Mainz, Germany) by sintering and melting Na2CO3, CaCO3, A1203 and SiO2 of p.a. quality. Compositions of the glasses used are given in Table 1. Tracer diffusivities of Na and Ca were studied by the residual activity method. Experimental technique and evaluation method are described in more detail by Behrens et al. (1990). 22NaC1 and 45CAC1 in aqueous solution were deposited on a well-polished surface of a bubble-free glass sample (typical size: 4 X 4 X 1 mm) and carefully dried. For runs at temperatures below 850 ° C samples prepared in this way were used directly for diffusion experiments. In order to exclude possible evaporation, samples for experiments at higher temperatures were pre-annealed for a short time at a temperature much lower than in the diffusion run to produce a thin isotope exchanged layer. Unreacted particles were removed ultrasonically with dilute nitric acid. Diffusion runs were carried out in a horizontal tube furnace at 1 atm. Samples were loaded on a sample holder with the activated side on top. Temperature was controlled with a Ptloo-Pt9oRhlo thermocouple, believed to be accurate to within _+5°C.

The run duration varied from 20 to 57,600 min depending on temperature and isotope used. The uncertainty in time is estimated to be less than + 2 min for heating and cooling of the sample. After annealing, the samples were checked by an optical microscope to be free of crystals. Only samples without crystals were taken into account. The penetration of the tracer was measured by successively sectioning the sample starting from the initially activated side. At the beginning and after each sectioning step the residual activity and the thickness of the sample were measured. The activity was determined for the y-emitter 22Na with a scintillation counter and for the fl-emitter 45Ca with a surface barrier detector (EGandG Ortec ® ). Thickness of the sample was measured with a micrometer (precision: _+1 pro). The analysed profile lengths varied from 30 to 800/zm. Tracer-diffusion coefficients were obtained from the slope of plots of the inverse error function vs. distance. An example is given in Fig. 1. For details of evaluation procedure see Behrens et al. (1990).

Including all significant sources of error (temperature determination, run duration, thickness determination, activity counting) one can estimate a maximum uncertainty of ~ _+20% for Na diffusion coefficients and ~ +25% for Ca diffusion coefficients. At low temperature the uncertainty is determined by the temperature dependence of the diffusion coefficient and by the profile length, at high temperature the run duration is more important. The higher uncertainty for Ca is due mainly to higher scatter of the activity measurements and to short diffusion profiles.

div.head: Results
div.p: Normal diffusion profiles characterized by straight lines in plots of the inverse error function vs. distance could not be obtained for all experimental conditions. Na tracer diffusion in An~oo and Ca tracer diffusion in An90 and Anloo glasses always displayed curved lines in such plots. For Na tracer diffusion in An90 and Ca tracer diffusion in An6o glasses in some cases normal profiles are obtained whereas in others not. Typically diffusion coefficients determined by a simple regression analysis are much smaller for runs displaying anomalous profiles as compared to normal runs. In some cases the difference was more than an order of magnitude. Only data from runs showing straight lines are included in Table 2. Examples for both normal and anomalous Na tracer-diffusion profiles are given in Fig. 1. Anomalous profiles for alkali diffusion were found also by other authors for SiO:-rich glasses (e.g., Frischat, 1970Frischat, , 1984;;Schaeffer and Mecha, 1974;Rothman et al., 1982). Frischat ( 1970Frischat ( , 1984) ) attributed this phenomena for Infrasil ® glass to the superposition of two different diffusion processes resulting from fine-scale inhomogeneities in this glass. An other possible explanation for anomalous behaviour is the presence of non-equilibrium conditions during the experiment as observed by K6hler and Frischat (1978) for Fe diffusion runs in an iron-containing glass.

There could be another explanation for the plagioclase glasses. Fig. 1 demonstrates that either an anomalous or a normal behaviour can be observed under the same experimental conditions. This suggests that neither structural reasons nor non-equilibrium conditions can be responsible for this phenomena. There is some evidence, from examination of activated samples with an optical microscope, that the contact between the sample and the surface layer formed by reaction with the tracer chloride can be at least partially interrupted during the anneal. Such an interruption would cause an additional transport resistance for the tracer. This effect should be strongly affected by the vapour pressure of the tracer and therefore be more important at low temperatures, and at a given temperature be more important for Ca than for Na.

In order to test the influence of pre-annealing on diffusion, double experiments were performed with the Ans0 and AnTo glasses using viation is within the experimental error, suggesting that at this temperature there is a minor influence of pre-annealing of the plagioclase glasses.

Samples from diffusion runs above 900°C were slightly rounded, but this had no significant influence on the diffusion coefficients. The experimental technique used in the present study is limited to temperatures up to 1000°C. At higher temperatures the shape of the samples changes too strongly and the glasses showed beginning of crystallization.

In Figs. 2 and both unannealed and pre-annealed samples. In both glasses, a slightly higher Na diffusivity was obtained at 800 o C for samples pre-annealed for 16 days at the same temperature before activation with the tracer (Table 2). But the de-
where Do=pre-exponential factor; Q=activation energy; R =gas constant; and T= temperature in kelvins).

The Na diffusivity values of the An6o glass give no indication for a change of slope in the Arrhenius plot, but no data could be obtained for temperatures above 800 ° C. Unfortunately, insufficient material of this glass was available to extend the data to higher temperatures. Na diffusion in the An9o glass is not well characterized due to the experimental problems discussed above. Only for comparison with the other glasses, the two low-temperature values were fitted by a straight line, giving Do and Q with unknown error. All Arrhenius parameters obtained are listed in Table 3.

div.head: I. Temperature dependence of Na diffusion
div.p: Changes of slope in Arrhenius plots of Na diffusion are often observed at the transition from a glass to a supercooled melt. Na diffusion in Na20-SiO2 glasses (Braedt and Frischat, 1988) and Na20-CaO-SiO2 glasses (Johnson et al., 1951) display inversely Sshaped curves. The temperature variation at low temperatures (glass) and high temperatures (melt) could be fitted by straight lines in Arrhenius plots. The activation energy is typically lower for the melt compared to the glass. Between the low-and high-temperature lines both the slope and the D-values can change more or less abruptly. The activation energy for this transitional range is typically higher than for the glass. This can be interpreted as the result of an increase of the free volume of the glass with increasing temperature above Tg (Braedt and Frischat, 1988). A transitional range is not always observed in glasses. For example, in xNa20" (1-x)Rb20-3SiO2 glasses inversely S-shaped curves are displayed for high Na20 content but for high Rb20 content there is a direct transition from glass to melt behaviour of Na diffusion (Braedt and Frischat, 1988).

This study on plagioclase glasses is the first one in which a change of slope at the transformation from a glass to a supercooled melt is observed for a tectosilicate glass. Taking all diffusion data below and above the kink in the Arrhenius plot into account straight lines can be fitted very well for the Anso and AnT0 glasses in the low-and high-temperature ranges (Fig. 2; Table 3 ). The activation energies are higher for the high-temperature range, suggesting that this is a transitional range from a glass to a supercooled melt. Due to crystallization of the samples the diffusion data could not be extended to higher temperatures in order to prove this.

The intersection points of both lines give Uncertainties given are 1 a errors from least-squares fitting. Data for Anoo and An too were calculated from diffusion coefficients published by: (*~) Jambon and Carron ( 1976); (,2) Jambon ( 1980); and ,3 ( ) Jambon and Delbove (1977).

temperatures Tg,Na, which can be used to characterize the relaxation properties of the glass. The values obtained for both glasses are Tg, Na= 712_+ 20°C for Ans0 and Tg,Na = 770 + 20°C for An7o. The uncertainty of Tg,Na was calculated from the 1 a error of leastsquares fitting. It should be noted that the scatter of the D-values is much smaller than the maximum experimental error given above.

The Tg,Na-Values given above are considerably lower than transformation temperatures Tg of the same glasses determined calorimetrically by M. Rosenhauer (pers. commun., 1991 ). Using cooling and heating rates of 18 K hr-~ he obtained Tg-values of 782_ 5 ° and 802_+ 5°C for the Anso and An7o glasses, respectively. The difference in transformation temperatures cannot be caused by different thermal histories, the same glass from the Schott ® laboratory being used as the starting material without any pre-annealing in both cases. Probably the relaxation processes defining the transformation temperature are not the same for both experiments. There may be significant changes in the structure of these glasses at temperatures below Tg, leading to higher Na defect concentrations without a visible effect on macroscopic properties such as volume expansion, viscosity or heat uptake. Data for Anoo are from Jambon and Delbove ( 1977 ), and for An~oo from Jambon (1980).

div.head: Compositional dependence of Na diffusion
div.p: creasing An content, especially for high-calcic plagioclases. Compared to pure Ab glass (data are taken from Jambon and Carron, 1976) the D-values at 800°C ofAnso, An6o, AnTo and An9o glasses are lower by factors 6.10-2, 1.5.10-2, 4.10 -3 and 6" 10 -5 , respectively. The difference between the diffusion coefficients becomes even larger at lower temperatures, since the activation energy increases with increasing An content. A quantitative interpretation of the compositional dependence is not possible due to different thermal histories of the glasses and also, in case of Ab and An, to different experimental procedures. According to Frischat (1975) different thermal histories can cause variations in D-values of an order of magnitude. But a qualitative interpretation should be possible because of the strong variation of the D-values along the Ab-An join.

Along the Ab-An join the AI/Si ratio increase with increasing An content. But studies of Frischat (1967), Heckman et al. (1967), andTerai (1968) have demonstrated for sodium aluminosilicate glasses that variation of this ratio only causes small changes in Na diffusivity. Also the concentration of NBO's has little influence on the mobility of Na in the sodium aluminosilicate glasses as stated by the same authors. Williams and Heckman ( 1964 ) and Terai (1968) reported a minimum in activation energy (maximum in D-values) for fully polymerized glasses (Na/AI= 1 : 1 ). The minimum is more pronounced in glasses with high SiO2 content, but the overall effect of compositional variation on Na diffusion in sodium aluminosilicate glasses is only of one order of magnitude for temperatures ranging from 200 ° to 700 °C.

The introduction of Ca in the melt is much more important for Na mobility. In both Na20-CaO-SiO2 glasses (Johnson et al., 1951;Frischat, 1970) and Na20-CaO-AI203-SiO2 glasses (Heckman et al., 1968) a considerable decrease of the Na diffusivity (increase in activation energy of Na diffusion) with increasing CaO content was observed.

The strong dependence of Na diffusivity on composition in plagioclase glasses may be explained by considering structural variations along the Ab-An join. An-rich glasses are more tightly packed than Ab-rich glasses. The room temperature density of An glass is only 2.2% lower than that of the crystalline phase, whereas it is 8.6% for Ab glass (Smith, 1974). Macroscopic properties and spectroscopic data for An-rich glasses indicate, in contrast to Ab-rich glasses, great similarities of the basic structural units to feldspar crystals. For example, An-rich glasses have much higher crystal growth rates than Ab-rich glasses (Kirkpatrick et al., 1976;Muncill and Lasaga, 1987). Raman spectra (Seifert et al., 1982) and X-ray radial distribution analysis (Taylor and Brown, 1979 ) are consistent with the presence of smaller (fourmembered) rings of tetrahedra as basic units in An glasses whereas in Ab-glass six-membered rings are dominating. Four-membered rings are also a characteristic feature of feldspar crystals. Engelhardt et al. (1985) concluded from their magic angle spinning-nuclear magnetic resonance (MAS-NMR) measurements that An glasses are fully polymerized and that Si is connected with four AIO4 tetrahedra as it is in the crystal. Binsted et al. ( 1985 ) found great similarities of energy-dispersive X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (EX-AFS ) spectra of Ca for An glasses and crystals.

The effect of introducing An component in the melt on Na diffusion can be explained in two ways. Firstly, the free volume of the glass is reduced. Therefore, the number of possible sites for Na is also reduced and the energy barrier for a jump of Na from one site to another is increased. Secondly, a part of the possible diffusion paths for Na can be blocked by Ca. Due to similar ionic radius Ca may occupy the same sites than Na but will be more strongly bonded at these sites due to higher charge.

div.head: Compositional dependence of Ca diffusion
div.p: In contrast to Na diffusion, there is only a small effect of glass composition on Ca diffu-sion. For example, at 800 °C the Ca diffusivity is higher only by a factor 5 in Ab glass (Ab data from Jambon and Delbove, 1977) than in the An60 glass. In Fig. 3 literature data of Ca diffusion in different silicate glasses are summarized. Comparison of the D-values suggests that the glass composition is less important than for Na diffusion. Only the data for Anlo0 from Jambon (1980) differ from this trend, but the activation energy of 644 kJ mol-1 is extremely high for diffusion of a divalent cation in a glass. It is not known whether or not experimental problems as found in the present study have been of influence in the experiments of Jambon (1980).

From the similarity of the Ca diffusion coefficients of the different silicate glasses, it is concluded that the properties of the diffusing cation itself and not the structural features of the glass are determining the mobility of the Ca cation. The local structure around the Ca cations may be similar for different glass compositions explaining similar diffusion coefficients of Ca.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In contrast to Ca diffusion, Na diffusion in plagioclase glasses is strongly dependent on the composition of the glass (An/Ab ratio). The compositional effect of Na diffusivity can be correlated to structural changes along the Ab-An join. This suggests that Na is an useful sensor for structural features of silicate glasses. This is not the case for Ca, its mobility in silicate glasses being probably mainly controlled by the local structure around the Ca cations, which may be similar for most silicate compositions.

Apparent transformation temperatures of plagioclase glasses determined from the Na diffusivities are lower than Tg-values determined calorimetrically. It is concluded that different relaxation processes determine Na diffusion and heat uptake.

Despite longer run time a much smaller D-value is obtained for the anomalous run (solid circles) showing a curved line in this plot.

Arrhenius plots are shown for Na and Ca diffusion, respectively. Diffusivity data from the literature are given for comparison. Na tracer diffusivities in Anso and AnTo glasses display marked changes of slope in plots of log D vs. 1/T. Both the high-and low-temperature ranges of these plots can be fitted well by straight lines according to the Arrhenius relationship:

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: The author thanks O. Diedrich for preparing samples and J. Koepke for performing electron microprobe analysis of the glasses. Thanks are also due to H. Schmalzried and W. Johannes for helpful discussions and to M. Rosenhauer who kindly provided the Schott ® glasses.
